title: General Paper 1 FQE (June 2018)
description: Final Qualifying Examination General Paper One from June 2018. Contains 30 questions covering Medical-Surgical Nursing, Pharmacology, and Anatomy.

questions.question: A skin condition characterized by non-infectious inflammatory lesions which are well defined with large adherent, silvery scales is:
questions.explanation: Plaque Psoriasis is classically described as raised, red patches covered with silvery-white scales.

questions.question: The chief manifestations of Parkinson's disease include:

options.text: Fatigue, weakness, numbness, difficulties in coordinating
Numbness, muscular rigidity, loss of balance
Impaired movement, muscular rigidity, tremors, muscle weakness

questions.explanation: Cardinal signs (TRAP): Tremor, Rigidity, Akinesia/Bradykinesia (impaired movement), Postural instability.

questions.question: While performing a physical examination of the abdomen, the correct sequence of the techniques is:
questions.explanation: Auscultation follows inspection to avoid altering bowel sounds via palpation/percussion.

questions.question: The inflammation of iris, ciliary body and the Choroid is known as:
questions.explanation: The Uvea comprises the Iris, Ciliary body, and Choroid. Inflammation is Uveitis.

questions.question: Coma in diabetic ketoacidosis is usually a result of:

options.text: Depressed cerebral function due to ketones/acidosis

questions.explanation: Ketone bodies and acidosis are toxic to the CNS, depressing cerebral function.

questions.question: The major blood groupings are determined by presence of:

options.text: Antibodies in the plasma and antigen on red cells membrane
Antigen in red blood cells and antibodies in white blood cells
Antibodies in Red blood cells and antigen on white blood cells
Antigens on red blood cells membrane, and antigen in the red cells nucleus

questions.explanation: Blood type is defined by Antigens on RBCs and corresponding Antibodies in plasma.

questions.question: Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by:

options.text: Painful joint, swollen joint, gradual onset
Inflamed joint, joint deformity, fixed joint
Joint thickening, hotness of the affected limb
Joint stiffness, painful joint, fever of 38Â°C

questions.explanation: RA causes symmetrical joint pain, swelling, and stiffness with a systemic/gradual onset.

questions.question: When caring for a patient on hemodialysis, the nurse will keenly monitor the patient for:

options.text: Hypotension, muscle cramps, chest pain and exsanguinations
Air embolism, chest pain, urine retention

questions.explanation: Hypotension (fluid shift), cramps, and bleeding/exsanguination (line separation) are major risks.

questions.question: The causative organism of syphilis is:
questions.explanation: Treponema pallidum causes syphilis.

questions.question: To prevent cross infection, the nurse should:
questions.explanation: Handwashing is the single most effective method to prevent cross-infection.

questions.question: Manifestation of cystitis include:

options.text: Dysuria, frequency of urination, urgency of micturition
Urgency of micturition, discharge, frequency of urination

questions.explanation: Triad of Cystitis: Dysuria, Frequency, Urgency.

questions.question: The priority nursing intervention for a patient with dry heat burns of the face, neck and chest includes:

options.text: Prevention of infections, hydrating the patient
Establishing patent airway, prevention of infections

questions.explanation: Burns to face/neck carry high risk of airway obstruction (inhalation injury). Airway is Priority #1.

questions.question: Effects of sympathetic nervous system input in the gastrointestinal system include:

options.text: Increased digestive juices secretion, increased motility
Decreased motility, decreased digestive juices secretion

questions.explanation: Sympathetic system (Fight/Flight) inhibits digestion: Decreased motility, decreased secretions, sphincter contraction.

questions.question: The common bacteria causing tonsillitis is:
questions.explanation: Group A Beta-Hemolytic Streptococcus is the common bacterial cause.

questions.question: Management of a patient with myocardial infarction include:

options.text: Moderate physical activity, high calorie diet

questions.explanation: Bed rest reduces cardiac workload. Low calorie diet reduces metabolic demand and gut blood flow needs during acute phase.

questions.question: During tracheostomy suctioning the nurse should:

options.text: Thin the secretions with 10mls of dextrose saline before suctioning
Suction from inside outwards in circular motions for 10-15 seconds
Suction the mouth and nose before suctioning the tracheostomy

questions.explanation: Circular motion prevents trauma. Limit to 10-15s to prevent hypoxia. Suction sterile trachea first, then mouth.

questions.question: Match the respiratory conditions with their descriptions:

pairs.right: Thin walled air spaces created by rupture of alveoli
Right heart failure secondary to lung disease

questions.explanation: Bullae are large air spaces. Corpulmonale is right-sided heart failure due to pulmonary hypertension.

questions.question: When conducting physical examination on a patient, the nurse expects evidence of diminished cardiac output to include:
questions.explanation: Low CO drops systolic pressure while diastolic stays stable/rises, narrowing the pulse pressure.

questions.question: When performing CPR to a child, the recommended ratio for chest compressions to ventilation for two rescuers is:
questions.explanation: 15:2 for 2-rescuer CPR in children/infants. 30:2 for single rescuer or adults.

questions.question: During the management of pulmonary tuberculosis the drugs used in the continuation phase treatment include:
questions.explanation: Continuation phase uses RH (Rifampicin + Isoniazid).

questions.question: State five (5) indications for hemodialysis (Mnemonic AEIOU).
Explain three types of sickle cell crisis.
Outline five (5) nursing diagnosis for a patient with burns of the back and the face.
Outline five (5) clinical features of hyperthyroidism.
Arrange the steps in the pathophysiology of Pneumonia:

items.text: Multiplication in alveoli and inflammatory response

questions.question: State six (6) side effects of anti-cancer drugs.
State five (5) nursing interventions for a patient with hip replacement surgery.
List six (6) complications of tractions.
Case Study: Bacterial Meningitis. Select correct features and management.

options.text: Mgmt: Bright lights to assess pupils

questions.question: Case Study: Peptic Ulcers. Select correct causes, pathophysiology, and management.

options.text: Pathophys: Imbalance between acid/pepsin and mucosal defense
Mgmt: Increase NSAID use for pain
